p: Alginate is a linear polysaccharide consisting of (1-4)-linked β-D-mannuronic acid (M) and α-L-guluronic acid (G) monomers, constituting M-, G-, and MG- sequential block structures [ 72]. It is naturally present in the brown macroalgae cell wall. Alginates are being used in various applications, such as alginate fiber wound dressings, as excipients in drug delivery, as dental impression materials, and preventing gastric reflux [ 73]. Alginates are also used for food protection, as gelling, thickening, coating, emulsifying, and stabilizing agents in food products [ 74, 75].
